senses.de: The ability to feel, see, hear, smell, or taste
senses.ex: She lost her sense of smell in the accident.

Tips.title: Sensory Loss
Tips.description: Discussing a loss of a sense often implies a medical condition or accident.
Tips.example: He suffered a loss of sense of taste after the illness.

Tips.title: Personal Variation
Tips.description: Some individuals have a heightened version of a sense, like a chef's sense of taste.
Tips.example: Her keen sense of smell helps her in her career as a perfumer.

senses.de: An understanding or awareness of something
senses.ex: She has a good sense of direction.

Tips.title: Skill Indication
Tips.description: Having a 'sense of direction' often implies a natural skill, rather than a learned one.
Tips.example: Thanks to his strong sense of direction, we never got lost during the hike.

Tips.title: Humor Appreciation
Tips.description: A 'sense of humor' refers to what someone finds funny, not the ability to joke.
Tips.example: Her sense of humor is very sarcastic, so she loves irony and wit.

senses.ex: It makes a lot of sense to invest in property.

Tips.title: Practical Advice
Tips.description: Saying something 'makes sense' often relates to practical or beneficial decisions.
Tips.example: Studying now makes sense since we have a test tomorrow.

Tips.title: Logical Understanding
Tips.description: We use 'sense' to express understanding logical arguments or explanations.
Tips.example: Her strategy makes sense for the budget constraints.

senses.de: To perceive or be aware of something
senses.ex: I can sense that she is upset.

Tips.title: Intuition Implication
Tips.description: Using 'sense' as a verb often implies intuition rather than direct evidence.
Tips.example: I sense that you're not telling me the whole story.

senses.de: A specific meaning of a word or phrase
senses.ex: The word has several different senses.

Tips.title: Contextual Meaning
Tips.description: The 'sense' of a word can change depending on context, like 'set' in sports or cooking.
Tips.example: In this sense, 'resolution' refers to determination, not solving a problem.

Tips.title: Interpretative Flexibility
Tips.description: A phrase may be interpreted in various 'senses', adding richness to language.
Tips.example: The poet used 'leaves' in the sense of both foliage and departure.

Aware.wordDefinition:
Aware means that you know or understand something, while the word sense refers to how you perceive or feel something through your senses.

For example, if you're aware of a fact, you know that it is true. But if you sense something, like a smell or a feeling, you experience it through your senses.

Awareness is typically used when referring to knowledge or understanding, while sense is used when referring to a physical sensation or feeling.

Feel.wordDefinition:
Feel usually refers to an emotion or a physical sensation that someone experiences through touch. For example - "I feel happy" or "I feel cold".

Feel usually refers to something personal and physical, whereas sense connotes perception and understanding.

Impression.wordDefinition:
Impression describes a feeling or opinion that is formed about something or someone based on a particular experience or observation.

For example, if you visit a new restaurant and come away feeling impressed with their food and service, you have formed a good impression of that establishment.

Impression specifically refers to an opinion or feeling that is formed based on a specific experience or observation, while sense is a more general term that can refer to any of the ways we perceive the world around us, as well as to our more vague or intuitive feelings about things.

Intuition.wordDefinition:
Intuition is a feeling or sense of something without any obvious reason or explanation. It's like a gut feeling about what you should do or what is about to happen.

Intuition is a feeling or sense that can't be explained, while sense relies on our five senses to pick up on things around us.

Intuition is best applied when we need to make a decision based on our inner sense, while our sense helps us make sense of our surroundings.

Perception.wordDefinition:
Perception refers to the way our brain interprets the information it receives through our senses (such as sight, sound, touch, taste, and smell).

It is a higher-level cognitive process that involves analyzing and making sense of sensory input. For example, when you see a tree, your brain uses your perception to identify it as a tree.

In simpler terms, perception is how we make sense of what we sense. Our senses provide us with the raw data, but our perception helps us interpret that data into something meaningful.

Sensation.wordDefinition:
Sensation refers to the experience or feeling we have as a result of these sensory experiences. Sensations are the subjective and personal interpretation of the stimuli we receive through our senses.

In summary, senses are the physical processes by which we perceive stimuli, while sensations are the personal experiences and feelings that result from those perceptions.

Sensibility.wordDefinition:
Sensibility refers to a person's emotional and sensitive nature. It is applicable in situations where one needs to empathize with others, be compassionate, and show emotional intelligence.

In simpler terms, sense is about being practical and logical, while sensibility is about being emotional and empathetic.

Understand.wordDefinition:
Sense and understand have similar meanings but they are used in different contexts.

Understand means to comprehend or grasp the meaning or significance of something, whether it's an idea, concept, language, or situation.

For example, we can understand a difficult math problem or a foreign language.

Sense refers to the ability to feel or detect something, while understand refers to the ability to comprehend or grasp the meaning of something.

quotes.Text: The most important thing, in anything you do, is always trying your hardest, because even if you try your hardest and it's not as good as you'd hoped, you still have that sense of not letting yourself down.
quotes.Title: English Actor
quotes.Name: Tom Holland

quotes.Text: Well first of all, it's hard to shoot a movie and break for a long time and then come back and do, in a sense, one of the biggest scenes that each character had.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Dustin Hoffman

quotes.Text: The truth of anything doesn't matter anymore. What's right doesn't matter. What makes economic common sense doesn't matter. I'm blue in the face over it.
quotes.Title: American Entertainer
quotes.Name: Rush Limbaugh

quotes.Text: I think it makes sense to believe in God, but exactly what decision in your life you make differently because of it, I don't know.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Bill Gates

quotes.Text: It's no wonder that truth is stranger than fiction. Fiction has to make sense.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: Mark Twain

quotes.Text: The world today doesn't make sense, so why should I paint pictures that do?
quotes.Title: Spanish Painter
quotes.Name: Pablo Picasso

quotes.Text: You feel a huge sense of responsibility when you're playing a real person.
quotes.Name: Jeremy Strong

quotes.Text: As I get older, I have a clearer sense of what's important to me.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Jennifer Connelly

quotes.Text: My biggest skill is common sense. I understand life.
quotes.Title: German Coach
quotes.Name: Jurgen Klopp

quotes.Text: It's important always to have a sense of wonder.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Julia Cameron
